page_analysis.text_content:
Porches & entry features

Facades with defined entryways make a streetscape pleasant and friendly as long as they are not out of scale or proportion.

The gross floor area regulations encourage appropriately sized porches and entryways.

Code sections
18.04.030(a)(65)
18.04.030(a)(113.1)
18.04.030(143.5)
18.12.040(b)table 3

Porch types

For purposes of assessing gross floor area, porches, entryways, and balconies fall into one of these categories:

1. Non-roofed porches, entryways, balconies etc.
  • Non-roofed features generally do not count

2. Roofed porches on the 1st floor (Fig 4 A & D on p. 7 , Fig 5 on p. 8)
  • Openess of the sides determines whether or not these count regardless of the height.
  • If they do count, they count only once.

3. Roofed entry features on the 1st floor that are less than 12' high (from grade) (Fig 4 B on p. 7)
  • These count once regardless of the design including openess.

4. Roofed entry features on the 1st floor that are more than 12' high from grade - "vaulted entry feature" (Fig 4 C & D on p. 7, Fig 6, 7, & 8 on pp. 11-13)
  • These count twice regardless of the design including openess.

5. Recessed porches on the 1st floor (Fig 9 on p. 14)
  • Height, depth, & openess determine whether or not these count.
  • If they count and are less than 17' high, they count only once.
  • If they count and are more than 17' high, they count twice.

6. Roofed balconies/outdoor areas on upper floors (Fig 10 on p. 15 )
  • These count once regardless of the design including openess

The following pages address the details of assessing these features with regard to gross floor area.

Difference between a porch & an entry feature:

A feature is considered to be a porch rather than an entry feature if it can clearly accomodate more activities than entering and leaving the house.

These figures presumably show examples or diagrams of porch types, roofed/non-roofed features, vaulted entry features, recessed porches, and roofed balconies/outdoor areas.

visual_elements.description: A shaded box titled 'Difference between a porch & an entry feature:' explaining that a feature is considered a porch rather than an entry feature if it can clearly accommodate more activities than entering and leaving the house.
visual_elements.location: Right side, middle of the page

visual_elements.description: A vertical shaded sidebar on the left side of the page containing introductory text about porches and entry features, emphasizing scale and proportion, and listing relevant code sections.
visual_elements.location: Left side, full height of the page

technical_specifications.parameter: Height threshold for roofed entry features to be considered vaulted
Height threshold for recessed porches to count once or twice

sections: 3. Roofed entry features on the 1st floor that are less than 12' high (from grade)
4. Roofed entry features on the 1st floor that are more than 12' high from grade - "vaulted entry feature"
6. Roofed balconies/outdoor areas on upper floors

additional_notes: The page contains no handwritten annotations or stamps.
The page is well structured with a left sidebar for introductory context and code references, main body text with numbered categories, and a right-side shaded box clarifying a key distinction.
The spelling of 'openess' appears multiple times and may be a typographical error for 'openness'.
Figures referenced are not visible on this page but are cited with page numbers for cross-reference.
cross_references: Fig 4 A, B, C, D on p. 7

qualifiers.text: For purposes of assessing gross floor area, porches, entryways, and balconies fall into one of these categories:

conditions.text: Non-roofed features generally do not count
Openess of the sides determines whether or not these count regardless of the height
If they do count, they count only once
Roofed entry features on the 1st floor that are less than 12' high (from grade) count once regardless of the design including openess
Roofed entry features on the 1st floor that are more than 12' high from grade count twice regardless of the design including openess
Recessed porches on the 1st floor: Height, depth, & openess determine whether or not these count
If recessed porches count and are less than 17' high, they count only once
If recessed porches count and are more than 17' high, they count twice
Roofed balconies/outdoor areas on upper floors count once regardless of the design including openess

logical_relationships.expression: If roofed entry features on the 1st floor are less than 12' high, then they count once
If roofed entry features on the 1st floor are more than 12' high, then they count twice
If recessed porches count and are less than 17' high, then they count once
If recessed porches count and are more than 17' high, then they count twice

execution_sequence.action: Determine if the feature is non-roofed; if so, it generally does not count
For roofed porches on the 1st floor, assess openness of sides to determine if they count
For roofed entry features on the 1st floor, check height to determine count multiplier
For recessed porches on the 1st floor, evaluate height, depth, and openness to determine count
For roofed balconies/outdoor areas on upper floors, count once regardless of design
